Form thin, flat, yellowish to dark-purplish blades just a single cell thick and spreading from a small holdfast. Hang from rocks in the high-shore. Flexible and slippery when wet, but become dry and crisp when exposed at low tide.

Originally just a single species was recognized from South Africa, but genetic work has shown that there are at least eight distinct forms along the west coast of South Africa but these still need to be formally diagnosed and described.
Blades typically about 150 mm, but can grow much larger.

Global: Genus widespread in cooler waters, but Southern African species are most-likely endemic to the region.

Local/Regional: Namibia to South coast, but most abundant on the west coast.

Form extensive coating hanging from intertidal rocks in the mid- to upper intertidal where few other algae survive and are extremely tolerant of water loss, becoming dry and crip on hot sunny days, but rehydrating once submerged.

Edible and fast growing. In Asia Porphyra has been cultivated for centuries and is known as nori. It is most often encountered dried in sheets and used as a wrapping for sushi. In South Africa small amounts are collected by health food enthusiasts and there is also interest in exploiting Porphyra as a feed for cultivated abalone.
The familiar macroscopic stage is the gametophyte and occurs as separate male and female individuals. These give rise to separate filamentous microscopic sporophytes.
Fairly easily identified to genus both by form and by the unusual ability to survive high on the shore. Local species still need to be resolved.

Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.
